I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will expand support of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to journalists in developing member countries (DMCs) to encourage 
high-quality journalism on a wide range of economic and social development issues in Asia and 
the  Pacific.1 Capacity-building  programs  are  designed  to  deepen  participating  journalists’ 
understanding of increasingly complex economic and social development issues, enabling their 
work to support public discourse and promote informed policy dialogue on issues relating to the 
achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The TA will deliver (i) a range of 
capacity-building programs such as training, seminars, and participation in ADB annual meetings 
to develop journalists’ technical skills and understanding of sector and thematic issues relevant 
to ADB’s Strategy 2030; and (ii) a regional forum on media and development in Asia and the 
Pacific. 
 
2.  ADB’s Strategy 2030 is aligned with major global commitments such as the SDGs and the 
Paris Agreement on climate change. It emphasizes ADB’s role as a knowledge institution, 
including the sharing of practical solutions that fit local conditions, and of information and 
experiences that enable countries to replicate good practices from across the region and beyond.2 
It also emphasizes the importance of tailoring the global development agenda to specific local 
circumstances and calls for integrating expertise across sectors and themes to address more 
complex development challenges (footnote 2). This TA will improve the contribution of journalists 
to greater public awareness of development issues and solutions, to increase the likelihood of 
their  adoption.  This  TA  is  included  in  the  2019–2020  work  plan  of  ADB’s  Department  of 
Communications (DOC). 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Development issues and challenges. Asia and the Pacific has made great strides in 
poverty reduction and economic growth since the late 1960s. However, the region has unfinished 
development agendas. Issues such as poverty and vulnerability, rising inequality, climate change, 
growing  environmental  pressures,  and  large  infrastructure  deficits  remain  to  be  addressed 
(footnote 2). Emerging trends such as technological advancements, urbanization, and changing 
demographics present challenges. Also, as developing Asia becomes increasingly integrated with 
the global economy and as its economic influence continues to grow, the need and demand for 
its perspectives and presence on global issues is rising. Given the size of Asia and the Pacific, 
achieving major global commitments such as the SDGs will depend critically on the success of 
the region and its people. 
 
4.  Low awareness of development issues and challenges. Turning global commitments 
from aspirations into achievements will require the understanding and active participation of all 
sectors of society. Limited awareness and understanding prevent stakeholders from engaging 
and acting on the SDGs. To promote urgent action on development issues, it is imperative to raise 
awareness  and  knowledge  among  a  wide  range  of  stakeholders,  from  local  and  national 
government officials to policymakers and regulators, to civil society organizations, businesses, 
and the public. 
 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 December 2019. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

2 
5.  Binding limitations and constraints faced by DMC journalists. The media, both 
traditional and nontraditional, have a significant influence on public beliefs, attitudes, opinions, 
values, and behavior. They are one of the most influential means of transmitting knowledge and 
information to a broad public audience. This power can be used to raise awareness of ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 priorities, including the SDGs, and promote positive actions.3 
 
6.  DMC journalists are key actors in this effort because they can influence the understanding 
of millions of readers, listeners, and viewers daily. However, DMC journalists face limitations and 
constraints.  Many  lack  the  resources  and  capacity  to  adequately  cover  a  wide  range  of 
development issues. They have few opportunities to study, report, and write about development 
issues. As the media landscape rapidly evolves and the complexity of development issues 
deepens, many journalists lack the skills as well as exposure to relevant information, context, and 
nuances to make sound judgements and produce well-informed and balanced news stories. 
 
7.  In response, ADB has been conducting annual capacity-building programs for DMC 
journalists  since  2014,  in  conjunction  with  its  annual  meetings.4 Various  funding  sources 
supported programs between 2015 and 2017.5 A small-scale regional TA: Capacity Building 
Program for Journalists in Developing Member Countries, 2018–2019 supported programs in 
2018–2019.6 More than 70 journalists from 33 DMCs attended the TA-funded programs.7 
 
8.  The programs provided unique opportunities for DMC journalists to learn about global 
development issues and interact with key actors from the development community in Asia and 
the Pacific. Field visits and interactive open sessions with experts from ADB and its knowledge 
partners contributed to a deeper understanding of economic and social development issues and 
led to in-depth media coverage. Program participants reported a high level of learning directly 
relevant to their work.8 Journalists produced significant coverage on issues such as sustainable 
development,  poverty,  economic  forecasts  and  economic  growth,  capital  markets,  energy, 
infrastructure development, governance, regional cooperation, and gender, on top of country-
specific topics such as transport and disasters triggered by natural hazards.9 
 
 
3  ADB sets seven operational priorities under its Strategy 2030: (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities; (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster 
resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability;  (iv)  making  cities  more  livable;  (v)  promoting  rural 
development and food security; (vi) strengthening governance and institutional capacity; and (vii) fostering regional 
cooperation and integration. 
4  The DMC journalist program began at the ADB headquarters in September 2014, followed by ADB’s sponsorship of 
selected DMC journalists to the 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019 annual meetings using various funding sources. 
5  Funding sources were the former Department of External Relations’ PR Outreach Budget (2015), Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility (2016), and Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund and Urban Environmental 
Infrastructure Fund (2017). 
6  ADB. 2017. Regional: Capacity Building Program for Journalists in Developing Member Countries, 2018-2019. 
Manila (TA 51358-001-REG, $225,000). 
7  The 33 DMCs are Afghanistan, Armenia, Bangladesh, Cambodia, the Cook Islands, Fiji, Georgia, India, Indonesia, 
Kazakhstan, Kiribati, the Kyrgyz Republic, Malaysia, the Marshall Islands, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nauru, Nepal, Niue, 
Pakistan, Palau, the People’s Republic of China, the Philippines, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, 
Thailand, Timor-Leste, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu, and Viet Nam. 
8  DOC. 2016. Report on Follow-Up Initiative with Participants to ADB-Organized Capacity Building Programs for 
Journalists in 2014, 2015, and 2016. Manila. The report assessed knowledge gains and professional advancement 
of the journalists with sustained access to ADB and good relations with ADB. 
9  In the follow-up survey, journalists reported that they published 90 articles about ADB operations and broad 
development issues during and immediately after the 2015 annual meeting, 200 articles in 2016, and 290 articles in 
2017. DMC journalists invited in 2018 produced 170, those invited in 2019 produced 205 articles.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: informed public debate in DMCs on economic 
and social development issues, including the SDGs, has been expanded. The TA will have the 
following outcome: DMC journalists’ coverage of complex social and economic development 
issues has improved.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
10.  Output  1:  Journalists’  capacity  to  report  on  complex  development  issues 
strengthened. The TA will support a range of capacity-building programs, such as training, 
seminars, workshops, and participation in ADB annual meetings. The programs will (i) develop 
reporting, research, and analytical skills, and foster greater data literacy; (ii) expand exposure to 
development issues and experts; and (iii) improve understanding of issues related to Strategy 
2030’s seven operational priorities. The programs will develop core content and include tailored 
information for national and subregional delivery to highlight locally relevant knowledge and 
experience, including exposure to ADB projects as appropriate. The TA will design and implement 
the programs in close collaboration with regional departments, resident missions, and sector and 
thematic groups. This output will result in a cadre of better-informed journalists across ADB DMCs, 
contributing to higher-quality journalism and public dialogue on development issues. ADB will 
partner with the academe, think tanks, and other public and private sector communication 
professionals to bring the latest know-how to journalism. ADB will coordinate closely with the ADB 
Institute in delivering selected capacity-building programs, as appropriate. 
 
11.  Output 2: Knowledge sharing and discussions on media and development issues 
enhanced. The TA will develop and hold a regional forum on media and development to 
encourage and enable knowledge sharing and experience exchange among journalists from 
DMCs, and interaction with leading journalists from global media outlets, selected knowledge 
partners, and senior ADB staff. The forum will facilitate discussion on the role of the media in 
supporting informed debate on economic and social issues and contributing to the implementation 
of the SDGs. Forum materials will be captured and disseminated widely among the journalistic 
and development communities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund—$525,000 (TASF 6) and $225,000 (TASF-other sources). 
The key expenditure items are in the cost estimates and financing plan (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. DOC will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and 
organize the training, seminars, workshops, and forums. ADB staff may serve as resource 
persons and provide administrative or secretarial support services. ADB will engage consultants 
and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time 
to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
14.  The TA will be implemented through an international consulting firm, an individual national 
consultant, and resource persons. The consulting firm with expertise in designing and delivering 
journalism training on development issues will be recruited using quality-based selection. One 
individual consultant will be hired to assist DOC with the delivery of the training, seminars, 
workshops, and forums.11 
 
15.  Following  approval  of  the  TA  and  mobilization  of  the  consultants,  DOC  will  hold 
discussions with operations and knowledge departments as well as with the ADB Institute to 
determine the detailed scope of the outputs and the implementation arrangements, including 
selection criteria and focus areas for the training, seminars, workshops, and forums. Participants 
will be identified in coordination with resident missions and external relations officers.12 
 
16.  The TA will also recruit resource persons and/or experts to support the training program 
and outreach activities. The TA will finance travel and per diem of ADB staff to act as resource 
speakers.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Building the Capacity of Journalists from Developing Member Countries in Asia and the Pacific, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants; and Terms of Reference for Resource Persons (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 3). 
12 Programs will strive to ensure diversity in terms of regional representation and gender. Journalists participating in 
programs at ADB’s annual meetings will be staff members of a DMC media organization with a wide circulation or 
audience and experience in covering development or economic issues. Other seminars, workshops, and training 
activities will also include early-career journalists and editors, and single-country activities will be reaching a wider 
range of national and local media. Output 2 will target mid-career or senior journalists and editors.
